origin: Old English on bæc  (see a-2, back). The term came to be treated as a single word in nautical use.

definitions.definition: towards or situated to the rear; back.
definitions.example: the little strip of pasture aback of the house

definitions.definition: with the sail pressed backwards against the mast by a headwind.
definitions.example: Peter holds the jib aback until our bow swings across the wind
